Graphical abstract Rh-based catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3–La2O3 modified with CeO2 promoter were prepared in the present work. The objective was to study the promotional effect of the addition of different CeO2 contents and 15wt% La2O3 on the stability of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for ethanol steam reforming reaction. The physico-chemical characteristics of the catalysts, activity and the deposition of carbon on the catalyst surface were surveyed by NH3-TPD, XRD, TPR, XPS, DRIFT, TPO-TG and Raman. The stability of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was effectively improved by the addition of 15wt% La2O3 and 5wt% CeO2, as the carbon deposition rate was reduced significantly (from 2.3 to 0.16mgcoke gcat −1 h−1). The role of the promoter was to decrease the selectivity to ethylene by modification of Lewis acid sites on the support and the removal of carbon deposits during the reaction. This is achieved through the formation of lanthanum oxycarbonate from La2O3 and higher amount of mobile lattice oxygen induced by the CeO2 promoter. This catalyst exhibited good selectivity to H2, with no presence of C2 intermediates above 723K; in addition this catalyst was stable up to 48h of time on stream at 773K. Furthermore, the original activity of the catalyst was recovered through regeneration by the removal of some carbon deposits which are potential causes of deactivation. Keywords Hydrogen production Ethanol steam reforming Rh catalysts CeO2 promoter 1 Introduction Decrease in fossil resources and current increased interest in protecting the environment have led to an imperative search of alternative energy sources. In this regard, hydrogen as energy carrier will play an important role in the energy systems of the future because it could be generated from several renewable sources and transformed into energy with high efficiency. Thus, the production of hydrogen from biomass is receiving increased attention as a potential source of renewable energy. Among the options for hydrogen production from biomass, the steam reforming of ethanol (SRE, Eq. (1)) represents one of the most promising methods because of the high availability of ethanol, its relative low cost and the high H2 production capacity of the process per molecule of ethanol reformed. (1) C H 3 C H 2 O H + 3 H 2 O → 6 H 2 + 2 C O 2 Δ H 298 ∘ = + 173.7 k J mo l − 1 From the thermodynamic point of view, since reaction (Eq. (1)) is endothermic and results in increase in number of moles, increasing the temperature and lowering the pressure is in favour of ethanol reforming [1]. However, high temperature (>973K) of SRE shifts the equilibrium of the water gas-shift (WGS) reaction (Eq. (2)) toward the formation of CO, which dictates further costly purification steps in order to remove CO. (2) CO + H 2 O → C O 2 + H 2 Δ H 298 ∘ = − 41.1 kJ mo l − 1 Moreover, carbon monoxide could undergo the Boudouard reaction (Eq. (3)) which is one of the main reactions responsible for coke formation [2]. (3) 2 CO → CO 2 + C Δ H 298 ° = − 172.5 kJ mol − 1 In addition, steam reforming reaction produces a wide range of undesirable by-products such as CH3COCH3, CH3CHO, C2H4, CH4, etc. and undesired reactions which contribute to catalyst deactivation by coke formation (Eqs. (4) and (5)). (4) n C 2 H 4 → oligomers + coke (5) C H 4 → 2 H 2 + C Δ H 298 ° = + 74.9 kJ mo l − 1 Development of suitable catalysts which are able to produce a H2 rich stream with very low CO concentration at medium or low temperature, and stable over time is still a challenge [3]. Different metals, Ni, Co, Pt, Rh, Ni/Cu, Pt/Ni deposited on different oxide supports (e.g. Al2O3, La2O3, ZnO, CeO2, MgO, etc.) have been studied for the ESR [4–9]. Among transition metals, the high CC bond-breaking activity and the high resistance to coke formation of Rh makes it one of the most studied active phase for this reaction [10–13]. It is generally accepted that the chemical nature of the support may strongly affect the products distribution and catalyst stability during SRE. Among oxide supports, alumina-based supports are often used in reforming catalysts because of their mechanical and chemical resistance under reaction conditions and the possibility that it offers to control the surface area and pore size distribution. Nevertheless, use of Al2O3 as support promotes catalysts deactivation by deposition of carbon from ethylene intermediate produced via dehydration reactions of ethanol on acid sites of the support. For that reason it is frequently reported in the literature the Al2O3 modification with addition of alkali metals, rare earths oxides and other basic oxides, which decrease the acidity, enhance the oxygen mobility, improve the metal dispersion and prevent the sintering of the metal sites [4,14]. Recently, Ferencz et al. [15] showed that metal reduction depended on the type of support used: cobalt could not be reduced to Co0 on alumina; on silica the reduction was almost complete; and on ceria, half of the Co could be reduced to the metallic state. Among used modifiers, La2O3 is known to be possess unique properties both as a support or a promoter because it forms lanthanum oxycarbonate species (La2O2CO3) which reacts with surface deposited carbon during reaction, and thereby minimize or avoid deactivation [4,16]. Likewise, CeO2 has also shown excellent results in catalysts stability as it favours coke gasification and WGS reaction due to its capacity to store, release and transport oxygen. Additionally, CeO2 improves the redox reversibility of metallic phase, prevents the loss of surface area of bare alumina support, and sintering of metallic species during thermal treatment [17–21]. On the other hand, Varga et al. [22], reported that CeO2 alone had a slight activity in ethanol steam reforming. Authors found that on CeO2 support, initially only acetaldehyde was formed, but between 650 and 800K the main product was ethylene while less amounts of acetone and CO2 were formed. The metal (Co) was mainly in oxidized state after the reaction. The aim of this paper was to study the promotional effect of the addition of different CeO2 contents and 15wt% of La2O3 on the stability and reaction pathways of Rh/Al2O3 catalysts for ESR reaction. γ-Al2O3 support was modified with both promoters in order to explore a possible synergistic effect between the two promoters, since each has shown excellent results individually on stability [14,23–26]. The effect of CeO2 on the physical-chemical characteristics, H2 selectivity, intermediates and reaction pathways and stability of the catalysts in the reaction of ethanol steam reforming at mild temperature (773K) was evaluated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Supports were prepared by successive wet impregnation of inorganic precursors of La2O3 and CeO2 in the order: La2O3–xCeO2–γ-Al2O3. xCeO2–γAl2O3 supports were prepared by impregnation of γ-Al2O3 (Glider S BET =189m2/g) with the appropriate amount of an aqueous solution of cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9% Merck) under stirring for 4h at room temperature, to obtain solids containing 2.5, 5, 10 and 15wt% CeO2. After impregnation, the supports were dried at 373K for 0.5h and finally calcined at 923K for 6h under static air. La2O3 (15wt%) was introduced into xCeO2–γAl2O3 and bare γ-Al2O3 supports using an aqueous solution of lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.9% Merck) as precursor. Rhodium catalysts (∼1wt%) were prepared in similar way by wet impregnation of the prepared supports using an aqueous rhodium chloride hydrate solution (RhCl3 H2O, 99.9% Aldrich). The calcination was performed over dried samples under dynamic air (30mLmin−1) at 573K for 4h at a heating rate of 10Kmin−1. The samples were designated as Rh/L(X)CA, where C=CeO2, L=La2O3 and A=γ-Al2O3. (X =2.5, 5, 10 or 15wt%). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area and porosity were obtained from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77K performed in an automatic Micromeritics apparatus Model ASAP 2010 on samples previously outgassed at 393K for 2h under N2 flow. The BET surface areas were calculated using a linear section of the BET plot based on IUPAC parameters. Pore-size distributions were calculated from the N2 adsorption branch using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda model (BJH). Metal dispersion was measured by H2 pulse chemisorptions on a Micromeritics ASAP 2100 unit. Prior to the pulse chemisorptions experiments, all samples were reduced under an in situ H2 flow for 1.5h at 923K. Subsequently, in order to remove hydrogen chemisorbed, vacuum was performed for 1h at 623K. Then, the systems were brought to room temperature and hydrogen isotherms were carried out. To calculate metal dispersion, an adsorption stoichiometry of H/Rh=1 was assumed [27], in spite of higher values reported for Rh/CeO2 catalysts. In fact, an H/Rh value close to 4 has been reported for ceria catalysts, which has been attributed to spillover effects induced by the support [28]. We assumed a H/Rh ratio of 1 because it has also been reported that hydrogen reduction treatments at 773K significantly reduced the reported ratio of 4 [29]; furthermore, the use of rhodium chloride as precursor could block the spillover process at room temperature [30]. Therefore, it should be possible to accept the usual adsorption stoichiometry used on the traditional supports. Particle size was determined by HR-TEM micrographs obtained in a JEOL TEM-2100F. Samples were dispersed on carbon grids after sonicating the samples in H2O:ethanol (50:50) for 0.5h. Up to 300 individual metal particles were counted for each catalyst. Total acidity was evaluated by temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). Samples (100mg) were reduced ex situ at 773K in H2 flow (30mLmin−1) for 1.5h just before analysis. Prior to NH3 adsorption, the supports were pretreated under He flow at 393K up to baseline stabilization and subsequently were ammonia-saturated at 373K using NH3 pulses. After saturation, weakly adsorbed NH3 was removed by flowing He at 373K for 0.5h. Subsequently, the system was brought to room temperature and desorption was carried out using a linear heating rate of 10Kmin−1 from 373 to 1073K. TPD curves were recorded by a TCD. All desorption profiles were normalized per gram of catalyst. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on reduced catalysts using a Bruker diffractometer Model D4 Endeavor and nickel filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15418nm) under constant instrument parameters. The test was carried out at 40mV and 20mA over Bragg angles between 5° and 90°. A rate of 0.02s per step (step size: 0.02° 2θ) was used during a continuous scan in the above mentioned range. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out with a semiautomatic Micromeritics TPD/TPR 2900 apparatus equipped with a TCD. Prior to reduction experiments, the samples (30mg), were thermally treated under air stream at 573K to remove water and other contaminants. TPR profiles were obtained by heating the samples under a 10% H2/Ar flow (50mLmin−1) from 298 to 1173K at a linearly programmed rate of 10Kmin−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to study chemical composition of the catalysts surfaces. Photoelectron spectra were recorded with a VG Escalab 200R electron spectrometer equipped with a Mg Kα X-ray source (hν =1253.6eV). The 50eV energy regions of the photoelectrons of interest were scanned a number of times to obtain an acceptable signal to noise ratio. Intensities were estimated by calculating the integral of each peak, determined by subtraction of the Shirley type background and fitting the experimental curve to a combination of Lorentzian and Gaussian lines (90G/10L). Accurate binding energies (0.2eV) were determined by referencing to the C 1s peak at 284.8eV. The reduction treatment was carried out ex situ at 773K in a H2 flow for 120min followed by reduction in situ at 723K for 30min. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation in the steam reforming of ethanol and characterization of used catalysts Activity tests were performed using 100mg of catalyst diluted with 200mg of SiC (both in the 0.18–0.36mm particle size range and selected after preliminary mass transport experiments to minimize diffusional resistances) to avoid adverse thermal effects. The catalyst bed was placed in a 1.7cm ID stainless steel tubular reactor with a coaxially centered thermocouple. Prior to reaction, the catalysts were heated in Ar flow (33mL min−1) up to 773K (10Kmin−1), followed by reduction in situ at 773K for 2.0h with H2 flow (30mLmin−1), and subsequently by a purge with Ar flow (33mLmin−1) for 1h. The mixture water/ethanol (3:1) was fed from a liquid phase by a HPLC pump (Gilson 307) with a flow 0.09mLmin−1 and then it was entered using Ar carrier gas with a total flow of 137mL min−1 under a GHSV=26,000h−1. The catalytic activity was measured at 773K for 24h of time on stream in order to study the catalyst stability. The reaction products were followed using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Hiden Model HPR-20) connected on line to the reactor through a heated capillary tube. The transient-MS signals at m/z =2, 15, 18, 26, 28, 29, 30, 31, 44 and 58 were continuously recorded for H2, CH4, H2O, C2H4, CO, C2H4O, C2H6, C2H5OH, CO2 and C3H6O, respectively. The intensity of each product was represented by the selected signal after subtracting the possible contributions of fragments from other compounds. Such contributions were calculated on the basis of the intensity ratios between the fragments characteristic of the individual molecules. The quantity of coke deposited on the spent catalysts was determined by temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) by thermogravimetry (TGA/SDTA851 Mettler Toledo), measuring the mass loss in the spent catalysts during oxidation. Each sample was previously heated up to 773K for 1h in N2 (10Kmin−1, 200mLmin−1) to remove volatile compounds adsorbed on catalyst surfaces. TPO were performed from 303K (5Kmin−1) until a final temperature of 1273K under flow of 20vol% O2 in N2. Quantification of coke deposited on catalysts was calculated according to the equation: C = m coke m used catalyst × t where m coke is the mass of coke deposited on the catalyst, calculated from TPO-TGA, m usedcatalyst is the mass of catalyst calculated from the mass remaining after the TG analysis, and t is the time under reaction. The nature and characteristics of carbon deposits were also studied by Raman spectroscopy. Raman spectra were recorded with a Renishaw via Raman microscope spectrometer equipped with a laser beam emitting at 532nm, at 100mW output power. Spectra acquisition consisted of 5 accumulations of 5s each, collected at room temperature. 2.4 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) Temperature-programmed desorption of ethanol (EtOH-TPD) and isothermal ethanol steam reforming experiments were studied by DRIFTS. DRIFT spectra were performed with a JASCO FTIR 6300 spectrometer equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled MCT detector and a KBr beam splitter. In situ experiments were performed using a DRIFT chamber (Spectra Tech) with ZnSe windows directly connected to a flow system equipped with mass flow controllers, saturators with ethanol and water, and a set of valves that allowed selection of feed gas composition. Prior to TPD analysis, the catalyst was reduced in situ under H2 flow at 723K for 1.5h and finally flushing under He flow (20mLmin−1) at 723K for 30min. For ethanol TPD experiments, ethanol was introduced into the DRIFT chamber by bubbling helium (30mLmin−1) through a saturator maintained at 303K by 0.5h. The first spectrum was recorded at room temperature after flushing under He flow for 0.5h. Then the temperature was increased stepwise up to 723K and spectra were recorded every 50K after equilibration for 2min on stream. The DRIFT chamber outlet was connected on-line through a capillary tube maintained at 473K to an Omnistar/Pfeiffer Vacuum mass spectrometer (MS) which was used for monitoring of effluent gas composition. The transient-MS signals at m/z =2, 15, 18, 26, 28, 29, 30, 31, 44 and 58 were continuously recorded for H2, CH4, H2O, C2H4, CO, C2H4O, C2H6, C2H6O, CO2 and C3H6O, respectively. For ethanol steam reforming reaction at 723K, the H2O:EtOH mix (3:1) was fed with a saturator. For isothermal experiments, only background at 723K was recorded. The intensity of each product was represented by the selected MS signal after subtracting the possible contributions of fragments from other compounds. Such contributions were calculated on the basis of the intensity ratios between the fragments characteristic of the individual molecules. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports and fresh catalysts The specific surface area, pore volume, metal dispersion and particle size of L(x)C doped and undoped Rh catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The specific surface area and pore volume of γ-Al2O3, progressively decreased by modification of the support with promoters (La2O3 and CeO2), indicating that these species produced changes in the textural properties of the alumina support. A possible explanation for the loss of surface area in the samples impregnated with promoters at high loadings may be the coverage of the pore walls of the γ-Al2O3 with oxide species. Some authors have found that at lanthanum oxide loading above 5wt% [31] and cerium oxide loading above 6wt% [32], the excess ions do not interact with the surface of the alumina support but rather blocks the porous structure of the support, possibly leading to the observed decrease in the surface area. This phenomenon is in agreement with the slight decrease in pore volume (Table 1), indicative of some introduction of oxide particles into the pores of γ-Al2O3. Rh dispersion, metal area and particle size, determined using H2 pulse chemisorption and HR-TEM are given in Table 1. As can be seen, the dispersion of Rh/A was lower compared to CeO2 containing catalysts. Addition of CeO2 to catalyst Rh/A increased the dispersion of the active metal, and as the CeO2 content increased the dispersion also increased and reached about 66.7% for the catalyst with 15% CeO2. HR-TEM results are in line with H2 chemisorption results, as shown in Table 1: adding promoters decreased average particle size and further narrowed the size distribution. The degree of dispersion in all the catalysts was high as typically observed for low Rh content catalysts. As has been widely reported [33–37], CeO2 is known to enhance the reducibility and the dispersion of the supported metal due to a strong interaction between metal and CeO2 which suppress their sintering. The catalysts acidity has a significant effect on the catalytic activity for ethanol reforming and the resistance to coke deposition. For this reason, total acidity of the catalysts was analyzed by temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and the total concentration of acid sites was given as the amount of ammonia adsorbed per gram of catalyst as shown in Table 2 . Catalyst supported on bare Al2O3 (Rh/A) showed an asymmetric desorption peak in the temperature range of 350–900K (Fig. 1 ). Desorption peak displayed a maximum at around 450K and a long tail. The desorption peak at low temperature confirmed the absence of Brønsted acid sites while the tail can be attributed to the presence of Lewis acid sites with different strengths [26]. La-doped support showed a slight decrease in acidity (Table 2), which proves that lanthanum incorporated on Al2O3 at a loading of 15wt% did not induce important changes in the total acidity although changes in the NH3-TPD profiles were observed. The NH3-TPD profile from this catalyst showed that modification of the support generated weaker Lewis acid sites, as was demonstrated by Yamamoto et al. [38] through IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine. The authors found that the addition of La at low loading titrates the original strong Lewis acid sites on γ-Al2O3 to form weaker Lewis acid sites; however, the increase in lanthanum loading increased the acidity as a consequence of the presence of deficiently coordinated La3+ ions acting as Lewis acid sites. By addition of Ce above 5% a more pronounced reduction in total acidity was observed (Fig. 1 and Table 2). The amount of adsorbed NH3 decreased from 0.145mmol/gcat for Rh/A to 0.074mmol/gcat for Rh/L(15)CA, indicating that this CeO2 loading strongly reduced the total amount of acid sites on the Al2O3 support. Nevertheless, as shown in Table 2 and Fig. 1, addition of CeO2 above 10% decreased the weak acidity/total acidity ratio related to Rh/A catalyst, thereby increasing those sites with higher strength. According to a study of surface characterization of CeO2–Al2O3 systems by in situ FTIR spectroscopy and adsorption microcalorimetry conducted by Morterra et al. [39], the presence of CeO2 adds a Lewis acidity of medium strength to the alumina mixed systems, which would agree with our results. The XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . All modifed catalysts showed diffraction peaks at approximately 2θ =37.2°, 45.8° and 66.7°, which correspond to γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 86-1410). Addition of La2O3 to bare Al2O3 support caused a sharp decrease on the intensity of the Al2O3 peaks which could be due to a structure disorder of the Al2O3 caused by lanthanum atoms highly dispersed on the Al2O3 structure. No diffraction peaks corresponding to crystalline species of neither La2O3 (JCPDS 83-1355) or LaAlO3 (JCPDS 85-1071) were observed in the supports and catalysts containing lanthanum. This indicates that lanthanum species are either incorporated into the pore structure of the alumina or highly dispersed on the surface as amorphous phases contributing to undetectable crystallites, in agreement with similar systems reported in literature [31,40]. The XRD peaks observed at 2θ of 28.6, 33.1, 47.6, and 56.5° were respectively indexed as (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of fluorite structure (JCPDS 081-0792) of CeO2, which suggests the segregation of the Ce-phase over the Al2O3 surface. As shown in Fig. 2, modification of Al2O3 with variable CeO2 loadings generates progressive changes in the intensity and in the shape of the γ-Al2O3 XRD peaks and a gradual increase of the CeO2 XRD peaks. These results suggest a crystallites growth of ceria with increasing Ce loading, which results in a partial coverage of alumina support. In all catalysts, XRD diffraction peaks corresponding to Rh species were not detected because the concentration of Rh in the catalysts is below the XRD detection limit. The TPR technique was used in order to know the type of reducible species formed on the catalysts after the calcination process. H2-TPR profiles of calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The Rh catalyst supported on bare Al2O3 exhibited a large peak at around 497K and two weak peaks around 430 and 780K. According to the results from the literature [41–45], reduction peaks below 553K correspond to both RhOx nanocrystallites with different sizes or RhO x species with different extent of interaction with the support. In the case of the peak at higher temperature, it has been reported that it corresponds to the reduction of Rh which interacts strongly with the support. This behaviour occurred because a fraction of Rh2O3 may diffuse into defect sites on Al2O3 and bound strongly to them [46]; however, rhodium aluminates species which are reducible at very high temperatures, 1073–1273K, were not detected for any of the catalysts studied. In the case of the La2O3-doped catalyst, two broad reduction peaks were obtained (Fig. 3b), a peak with low area with maxima at 450K and a much more intense peak between 650 and 900K, with maxima at 740K. The appearance of the peak at the highest temperature for the Rh/LA catalysts compared to the bare Al2O3 indicates that there is a significant interaction between rhodium oxide and the La2O3 promoter. Some authors [47,48] have attributed this signal to the formation of LaRhO3-like species. Borer and Prins [47] reported that modification with increasing La2O3 amounts of Rh/SiO2 catalysts shifted the TPR peaks to higher temperature, and generated much broader peaks. They suggested that La2O3 stabilized Rh2O3 towards reduction by hydrogen, even at low La concentrations. Therefore, it is possible to affirm that the appearance of a peak at a higher temperature observed by addition of La2O3 (Fig. 3) implies that Rh2O3 particles are in intimate contact with La oxide. In addition, the higher signal observed for La-containing catalyst can be related to the reduction of La-oxycarbonate species, whose remotion requires calcination temperatures above 973K [48], that overlaps with Rh2O3 reduction. By adding increased CeO2 amounts, the two peaks observed for Rh/LA are shifted to lower temperature, suggesting that this promoter weakened the Rh–La interaction mentioned. The reduction peak of rhodium oxide could be overlapped with that of the surface ceria. According to the literature [16,49,50], the TPR profile for pure CeO2 is characterized by two consecutive reduction steps, one weak peak at around 840K ascribed to the surface CeO2 reduction and the other above 1100K ascribed to the reduction of bulk ceria. In our case, the reduction temperature of surface CeO2 may have appeared at lower values because Rh0 has high activity in dissociative chemisorption of H2, which subsequently spillovered to the surface CeO2 and promoted its partial reduction. The reduction of CeO2 at lower temperatures is suggestive of the existence of strong interactions between Rh and CeO2 phases [51]. The reduced Rh/L(X)CA catalysts were analyzed by XPS to study the oxidation state and surface composition. The binding energies of core electrons and the surface atomic ratios of the reduced catalysts are summarized in Table 3 . XPS results of the catalysts under the study are summarized in Table 3. La 3d5/2 spectra with BE between 835.7 and 835.1eV were observed, which was substantially higher than the values reported for La2O3 (833.2eV) and LaAlO3 (833.8eV) standards. However, our values have already been reported by some authors [25,52,53] and have been attributed to deficiently coordinated La3+ ions. Therefore, it confirms that for all the catalysts La2O3 (15wt%) is highly dispersed on the support. In addition, the calculated La/Al atomic ratio (Table 3) was higher than the values corresponding to the bulk composition which is indicative of a good diffusion at surface level of lanthanum ions into the alumina framework. The Ce 3d spectra of the Ce-containing catalysts consist of several peaks resulting from either multiplet splitting or shake-up processes (Fig. 4 ). The isolated peak in the Ce 3d spectra at ca. 917eV (u’’’ using the nomenclature of Burroughs) [54] has been used as identification of Ce4+ species and its relative peak area contribution to total Ce 3d area as quantitative measure of the amount of Ce4+. The fraction of the total Ce signal attributable to the u”’ peak (Table 3) in the reduced catalysts was highest for the Rh/L(15)CA catalyst. The lower Ce/Al atomic ratios compared to the nominal values, observed for the Ce-containing catalysts above 2.5%, is indicative of CeO2 agglomeration on support surface confirming the observations deduced from XRD results. The reduced catalysts showed a Rh 3d5/2 peak at binding energy of 307.0–307.6eV. This peak can be ascribed to metallic rhodium, although the binding energy appears slightly above the Rh0 state. The observed shift in binding energy may be consequence of either the smaller size of the rhodium or the strong interaction with support, leading to an electronic polarization of the clusters of rhodium. Interaction beetwen Rh and support was also suggested by H2-chemisorption and TPR results. Regarding Rh/(Ce+La+Al) atomic ratio (Table 3), a Ce loading above 2.5% gave rise to a higher Rh dispersion, as atomic ratio determined by XPS was higher than nominal value for modified catalysts with 5, 10 and 15% of CeO2. The amount of exposed rhodium atoms in reduced catalysts determined by XPS is in line with that determined by H2 chemisorption and HR-TEM (Table 1). 3.2 Ethanol steam reforming reaction The performance of the catalysts studied during ethanol steam reforming was evaluated in terms of ethanol conversion and products distribution as a function of time on stream. Given that catalyst deactivation by coke formation is a fact inherent to ESR and the extent of coking is a key factor for the choice of the catalyst, determination of the effect of the modification of the support with promoters on the stability and amount of coke depositedwere evaluated. The stability measurements (Fig. 5 ) were carried out for 48h at 773K, and the spent catalysts was characterized. The experiments were performed at GHSV of 26,000h−1 under very high inlet ethanol concentration (ca. 14vol%) and molar ratio of 3, conditions necessary to enhance the catalyst deactivation phenomena. All catalysts attained complete conversion during the first 5h of reaction and remained stable above 65% until the end of the reaction. The Rh/L(15)CA catalyst showed the highest deactivation at 48h (66%) (Fig. 5). Regarding the products distribution, all catalysts displayed the same products but with different distribution. The main observed products in all cases were H2, CH4, CO, CO2, acetaldehyde, acetone and ethylene. At the beginning of the reaction (0.5h), Ce-containing catalysts below 15% exhibited the following order of selectivity: H2 >>CH4 ≥CO2 >CO, which remained stable during 5h of reaction. Rh catalysts supported on bare Al2O3 (Fig. 5(1)) and with 15% CeO2 showed the highest selectivity to CO (ca. 19%) and to ethylene (ca. 14%) of all the catalysts at the start of the reaction. In addition, it exhibited the lowest selectivity to CH4 (<4%). It should be noted that during the first 5h of reaction no significant changes in the products distribution for doped catalysts below 15% CeO2 were observed, while the unmodified catalyst and with 15% CeO2 suffered substantial changes as the reaction proceeded. On the other hand, Rh/L(15)CA catalyst exhibited a completely different selectivity compared to the modified catalysts. The selectivity followed the order: H2 >>CO>C2H4 >CO2 >acetaldehyde≈acetone>CH4. This was the only catalyst that showed the formation of C3 species from the beginning of the reaction. The highest selectivity to ethylene with these two latter catalysts mentioned (Fig. 5(1) and (6)) indicates that at this temperature (773K) the dehydration of ethanol is favoured on this type of catalyst. The presence of acetone in Rh/L(15)CA catalyst showed that acetaldehyde undergoes aldol condensation reactions subsequent to its formation (Eq. (6)). This point out that the promotion of CC bond cleavage by Rh is inefficient in this catalyst and therefore, decarbonylation of acetaldehyde competes with the aldol condensation which leads to the further formation of acetone [6]. The appearance of acetaldehyde and ethylene in the reaction products suggests that both dehydration and dehydrogenation reactions (Eqs. (7) and (8)) are favoured to different extents in the catalysts. (6) C H 3 CH O + O ( l ) → C H 3 C O C H 3 + C O 2 + H 2 (7) C H 3 C H 2 O H → C H 3 C H O + H 2 (8) C H 3 C H 2 O H → 2 C 2 H 4 + H 2 O According to the products distribution observed, it appears that ethanol and reaction intermediates such as acetaldehyde undergo decarbonylation (Eqs. (9) and (10)) and subsequent reactions that favour the formation of CO2, as WGS reaction (Eq. (2)), giving H2, CH4, CO2 and CO as main products over doped catalyst with CeO2 loading until 10%. (9) C H 3 C H 2 OH → C H 4 + CO + H 2 (10) C H 3 CHO → C H 4 + CO Given the highest selectivity to CO and lowest to CO2 observed for R/L(15)CA and Rh/A catalysts, respectively, it is possible to affirm that the WGS reaction is not favored over these catalysts. The presence of an adequate amount of both promoters (CeO2 and La2O3) in the support greatly improved the catalytic activity of the catalysts in the ESR reaction at mild temperatures. Further selectivity to acetaldehyde, acetone and ethylene decreased illustrating the high capacity to break CC bond compared with Rh catalysts supported on bare Al2O3 or with high Ce loading (15%). After 48h of reaction, all doped catalysts with CeO2 up to 10% showed a decreased of selectivity to H2 and CH4 and an increase of selectivity towards CO (Fig. 5). In addition, a slight increase in selectivity to C2 and C3 species was observed in all cases, with a minimum value for the Rh/L(5)CA catalyst. An increase in selectivity to acetaldehyde, ethylene and acetone in gas phase products afterwards 48h of time on stream, confirms catalyst deactivation because the capacity of CC bond breakage is diminished, as the selectivity to these products was minimal at the beginning of the reaction. It is worth pointing out that the Rh/L(15)CA catalyst showed the highest selectivity to C2 and C3 intermediates after 48h of reaction; therefore, it is possible to affirm that CeO2 addition below 10% decreases selectivity to C2 and C3 products compared with the bare alumina support. On the other hand, the lower selectivity to CH4 after 48h of time on stream obtained over the catalyst supported on modified alumina suggests that desactivation can be related to dehydrogenation of methyl groups which can lead to the accumulation of carbon deposits (Eq. (11)). (11) C H 3 ( ads ) → C H 2 ( ads ) + H ( ads ) → C H ( ads ) + H ( ads ) → C ( ads ) + H ( ads ) In comparing the Ce-modified catalysts, the Rh/L(5)CA catalyst showed the lowest selectivities to C2 and C3 products, indicating that this catalyst had the lowest deactivation after 48h of time on stream compared with the doped catalysts. Rh/A and Rh/L(15)CA catalysts showed substantial deactivation at the end of reaction with the lowest selectivity to H2 (<20%). For the Rh/A catalyst, the main products after 48h of reaction were C2H4 >CO>H2 >acetone>acetaldehyde, which points to the dehydration reaction being favored with time on stream possibly as a result of catalyst deactivation. In the case of Rh catalyst modified with 15% CeO2, a higher selectivity to CO2 than the beginning of the reaction can be noted, which can be due to the occurance of the Boudouard reaction (Eq. (3)). Both Boudouard reaction as the polymerization of C2H4 (Eq. (4)) can contribute to catalyst deactivation by coke formation, as determined by characterization of the spent catalysts. Based on the results presented, the Rh/L(5)CA catalyst was selected for catalyst regeneration test after deactivation under time on stream. Fig. 5(4)–(6) shows the results obtained during a reaction period of 72h, followed by five reactivation cycles. First, it can be observed that at 72h the selectivity to H2 sharply decreased (from 73 to 42%), and, consequently, selectivity to undesired products increased, while conversion dropped slightly. It is clear that the active sites have been deactivated probably by coke deposits formed in the course of the reaction which increased the selectivity to ethylene and acetaldehyde; this observation indicates that catalyst has lost its ability to break the CC bond and hence this reaction is slower after 48h. As shown in the literature, the deactivation mechanism on this type of catalysts is mainly due to the formation of carbonaceous deposits on the active phase [10,11,46,55,56]. Thus, a reactivation process based on the heat treatment of the catalysts at 723K for 1h under an air stream (100mLmin−1) was carried out to burn-off the carbon deposits and recover the initial activity. A similar catalytic behaviour regarding the products distribution and restoring the conversion to those observed under the 48h of time on stream was observed after first reactivation. Subsequent catalyst reactivation processes did not fully regenerate the catalyst to the initial activity, although conversion above 80% was observed until the fifth reactivation. Changes in the products distribution shows that the active phase has been modified, although its activity in the conversion and H2 selectivity was still high throughout the experiment. Above the third reactivation, selectivity to CO and CO2 and C2 products such as ethylene, ethane and acetaldehyde increased significantly. The appearance of these products indicates a diminished capacity of the catalyst to the formation of C1 products. The products distribution points out that CO is produced via decomposition of acetaldehyde, which then undergoes further Boudouard reaction to form CO2, leading to decrease of the selectivity to H2. The fact that in the last reactivation processes subsequent deactivation occurred more rapidly indicate that some amount of permanent damage took place and hence catalyst did not return to its initial chemical and/or structural state after air treatment. However it is possible to affirm that the Rh/L(5)CA catalyst was stable and showed good results in terms of conversion and selectivity to H2 to the third reactivation. Considering the results of conversion, selectivity and catalyst stability with time on stream, it is plausible that the main reaction pathways were dehydration to produce ethylene or dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde species. For most of the catalysts, the presence of C2 and C3 intermediate products such as acetaldehyde, acetone, ethylene and ethane were observed. The selectivity to these products was highest for Rh catalyst supported on bare alumina and dope-alumina with 15% CeO2. On the other hand, the formation of C1 species was favoured for Ce-containing catalysts with CeO2 loading not exceeding 10% CeO2. One of the main causes of deactivation in the former catalytic systems is due to the deposition of carbonaceous species. The main reactions that contribute to coke formation during ethanol reforming reaction are as follows [57]: (i) ethanol dehydration to ethylene (Eq. (8)), followed by polymerization to coke (Eq. (4)); (ii) aldo condensation of acetone followed by dehydration to mesityl oxide (MO) (Eq. (12)); (iii) the Boudouard reaction (Eq. (3)) and (iv) the decomposition of methane (Eq. (5)). The latter two routes are primarily responsible in limiting the catalytic activity at high temperatures. The aldol condensation of acetone produces diacetone alcohol, which can subsequently suffer dehydration to mesityl oxide (MO) [58], and whose oligomerization can lead to the formation of coke [59]. (12) 2 CH 3 COCH 3 → ( CH 3 ) 2 C ( OH ) CH 2 COCH 3 ( CH 3 ) 2 C ( OH ) CH 2 COCH 3 → ( CH 3 ) 2 C = CHCOH 3 + H 2 OH 2 O The early deactivation of Rh/A catalyst from the beginning of the reaction can be due to polymerization reactions of ethylene that block the catalyst metal sites. As displayed in Fig. 5(1), the bare alumina catalyst shows the highest selectivity to ethylene throughout the reaction. Polymerization of ethylene to coke takes place on both strong Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the support that results in the formation of polynuclear hydrocarbons, which remain strongly adsorbed on acid sites and cause loss in activity or form coke multilayers that lead to catalyst poisoning [57]. As shown in TPD profiles (Fig. 1), the Rh/A catalyst possess strong Lewis acids sites which would promote the ethanol dehydration and subsequent reactions from ethylene. The highest amount of ethylene detected for this catalyst is consistent with the carbon build-up observed (Table 4 ). The addition of La2O3 and CeO2 to Rh/A catalyst induced several changes in the acid-base properties of the support. As can be seen in Fig. 1 and Table 2, modification of alumina led to a decrease in the concentration of total acid sites and the appearance of new weaker Lewis acid sites, resulting in lower production of ethylene and therefore, less carbon deposits. Thermogravimetric analyses of the spent catalysts were carried out to calculate the amount of carbonaceous residues retained in the catalysts after reaction by measuring the weight loss during its temperature programmed oxidation under oxygen gas flow. The amounts of carbon deposited on spent catalysts calculated from TGA data are shown in Table 4. The Rh/A and Rh/L(15) catalysts displayed a high capability of carbon deposition during ESR at 773K. It is noteworthy that for the Rh/L(15)CA catalyst the deactivation and the amount of deposited carbon are as high as for those obtained on unpromoted Rh/A. This can be mainly explained due both to ethylene polymerization and Boudouard reaction according to selectivity observed in TOS experiments. The presence of intermediate and/or stronger acid sites on this catalyst, compared to other doped catalysts, favoured the ethanol dehydration as it confirmed by detection of ethylene in the reaction products (Fig. 6 ). These observations support the conclusion that it is not sufficient to diminish the total acidity to prevent formation of carbon via ethylene. The high coke deposition measured on these spent catalysts is correlated to the observed deactivation during the reaction. With the doped catalysts below 15% CeO2 the formation of carbon is markedly suppressed as indicated by the lower carbon deposition rate (Table 4). The Rh/L(5)CA catalyst exhibited the lowest carbon deposition rate value compared with the other catalysts evaluated, as well as compared with some data reported in literature for similar systems [46,55,60]. The nature and characteristics of carbon deposits were also studied by Raman spectroscopy which has shown to be a powerful technique for characterizing the structure of carbon deposits. The results confirmed the presence of graphitic carbon species deposited on the catalyst during the reaction. In Fig. 7 , the Raman spectra of used samples are shown in the range of 1200–1800cm−1. In all the cases, two broad bands centered at 1600 and 1350cm−1 were observed. The peak at 1600cm−1 (G band) is related to sp2-bonded carbon atoms in a two dimensional hexagonal lattice, such as in a graphite layer [61]. The peak at 1350cm−1, the so-called D band, is associated with allotropic forms of carbon (carbon nanotubes, amorphous carbon and defective filamentous carbon). The presence of both signals, G and D, shows the heterogeneity of the carbon species formed during the SRE. The intensity of the D band, relative to the G band, provides information on the degree of graphitization of the deposited carbon. As shown in Table 4, this ratio was similar for the catalysts, although it is possible to affirm that the doped catalysts with 2.5 and 5% showed greater disorder in their carbon structures, compared with the value for commercial graphite with crystallite sizes of 11nm (ID/IG ratio is 0.39) [62]. According to these results, the nature of support strongly influenced the stability of the catalysts during reforming reaction by contributing to reduction of ethylene production and promoting the oxidation of carbon precursors deposited on rhodium surface during the reaction. The La2O3 promoter has been suggested to react with carbon dioxide to form lanthanum oxycarbonate species (Eq. (13)). Participation of lanthanum phase through formation of La2O2CO3 can explain the differences in carbon formation on La-containing catalysts. It has been reported that the La2O2CO3 species can reacts with carbon-metal species (C–Mn) formed in its vicinity, to produce two molecules of CO (Eq. (14)) [63]. Thus, La2O3 acts as an intermediate, promoting the reaction between the carbon species and CO2. (13) La2O3 +CO2 ⇄La2O2CO3 (14) C − M n + L a 2 O 2 C O 3 → 2 C O + M n + L a 2 O 3 On the other hand, CeO2 contributes to the decrease of the carbon deposition rate due to its reduction/oxidation capability by releasing and uptaking oxygen. The oxygen lattice provided by CeO2 may oxidize the solid carbon according to the following reaction (Eq. (15)): (15) C ( s ) + O ( l ) → O ( l − 1 ) + COl = lattice The results indicate that the metallic site is in close contact with the promoters of the support, given the pronounced increase in stability observed by modifying the bare alumina with both promoters, which is in agreement with characterization results. Some authors [61,64] have suggested the decoration of metallic particles to be responsible for decrease in the rate of formation of carbon deposited during reaction. Even though there is no evidence from our result to suggest decoration of Rh particles, it can be deduced from the significant reduction in the formation of carbon deposits by the modification of support (Table 4) that there was an intimate contact between the metal particles and the promoters on the support. In other hand, Fig. 8 shows the HR-TEM images of the used catalysts. Obviously, heavy coke deposition was the main reason for the deactivation of the Rh/A and Rh/L(15)CA catalysts, in addition to the sintering of metal particles as shown in Table 4. The carbon deposited grew around the Rh particles and also aggregated into rather large particles. However, the particle size of Rh/L(X)CA with 2.5≤×≤10 only slightly increased to about 2.0nm and no significant deposited carbons could be observed over the used Rh/L(5)CA catalyst. As mentioned above, the strong metal-support interaction with the CeO2 promoters effectively prevented the sintering of the highly dispersed Rh particles and the enhanced oxygen storage-release capacity of ceria greatly facilitated coke gasification. 3.3 In situ DRIFT characterization of ethanol temperature programmed desorption and reforming Temperature programme desorption of ethanol and steam reforming of ethanol has been investigated by means of in situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy in order to identify surface adsorbates and species formed during the reaction and to explain its role in the deactivation processes. Infrared spectra recorded in the EtOH-TPD test for Rh catalyst supported on bare alumina and 15% La2O3-5% CeO2–Al2O3 are depicted in Fig. 9 . This latter catalyst was chosen because it showed the best results regarding selectivity and conversion after 48h, as well as the lowest carbon deposition rate. Upon adsorption of ethanol at RT the IR bands at ca. 2970, 2930 and 2900cm−1, which are ascribed to ν as(CH3), ν as(CH2) and ν s(CH3), respectively, are observed in both catalysts. These bands, along with bands visible at 1450, 1390, 1163, 1100, 1080 and 1060cm−1 asigned to δas(CH3), δs(CH3), ν(C–O or C–C), ν as(CCO) monodentade, ν(C–C) and ν as(CCO) bidentate, respectively, demonstrate the existence of surface ethoxide species due to ethanol adsorption. In addition to the mentioned bands, a strong band is detected at 970cm−1, ascribed to the ρ(CH3) vibration in η2(C,O)-acetaldehyde [65], that originated from ethanol dehydrogenation (Eq. (7)) over the surface of the catalyst. Acetaldehyde presence is confirmed by band between 1620 and 1709cm−1 assigned to the v(C=O) stretching of adsorbed acetaldehyde species in its η1-configuration [66–69]; however, bands in this range have also been ascribed to ν modes of adsorbed crotonaldehyde, formed by the β-aldolization of two acetaldehyde molecules [6], and hence this species can not be ruled out eventhough it was not observed in the gaseous products detected by mass spectrometry. The Rh/L(5)CA catalyst at this temperature also showed bands in the carbonyl region (2030–1800cm−1) typical of CO species linearly adsorbed on Rh particles. The evolution of surface species on catalysts with the increase in desorption temperature is different depending on the presence of promoters in the support. With the increase in desorption temperature, the sample supported on bare alumina (Rh/A) showed a decrease in the intensity of bands corresponding to molecular ethanol, an enhancement in the bands corresponding to carbonyls on Rh (linear and bridged) and the appearance of bands at 1570 and 1460cm−1 assigned to ν as(COO−) and ν s(COO−) stretching of acetate species, respectively. Evolution of surface species on Rh/L(5)CA catalyst with the increase in desorption temperature showed absorption bands associated to carbonyl species on Rh, in this case only in linear form, and the growth of an asymmetric broad band in the region of 1400–1600cm−1. This band could be associated to the formation of carbonates (ν(CO)=ca. 1530–1560 and 1340–1380cm−1), acetates or formates groups which show absorption bands at ca. 1340–1400cm−1 (ν s(COO)) and ca. 1550–1620cm−1 (ν as(COO)) [70,71]. The lower intensity of the band at ca. 1450cm−1 , with respect to the band at ca. 1570cm−1 observed in this catalyst (Fig. 9(B)), indicates that a minor amount of acetate is present with respect to the other species (formate and carbonate). The typical spectrum for acetate species show similar intensities for symmetric and asymmetric vibration bands while for formates species, the symmetric band is only about 1/3 of asymmetric band [72]. The lowest amount of acetate species in the case of modified catalyst is supported by the almost complete disappearance above 573K of the bands corresponding to the CH stretching region; in contrast, on the catalyst supported on bare alumina these bands weremore stable, as was also observed by Ferencz et al. [15]. The detection of acetaldehyde and acetate species adsorbed reveals that dehydrogenation reactions (Eq. (7)) and its subsequent oxidation of intermediate (Eq. (16)) is occurring on the catalyst. (16) C H 3 CHO + OH → C H 3 COO + H 2 Formate intermediate is probably originated by the reaction of bridging OH groups with adsorbed CO (Eq. (17)). The detection at low temperatures of CO and formate species adsorbed on the surface, in addition to the presence of H2 and C1 species (CO, CH4 and CO2) in gas phase in DRIFT cell exit (not shown), show the highest capacity of this system to break the CC bond. A progressive increase of temperature gives rise to a decline in the intensity of adsorption bands corresponding to CO species and a rise in the intensity of acetate and formate bands up to 673K in promoted catalyst. Above this temperature, these bands begin to decrease suggesting decomposition of acetate (Eq. (18)) and formate species (Eq. (19)), that results in formation of H2, CO2 and methane species. On bare alumina catalyst a progressive increase in the acetate bands is observed up to 723K, pointing to that acetate intermediate accumulates on the surface. (17) C O ( ads ) + O H ( ads ) → HC O O ( ads ) (18) C H 3 C O O ( ads ) → C O 2 + C H 4 (19) HCOO(ads) ⇄CO2(ads) +1/2H2 The in situ DRIFT spectra obtained during ethanol steam reforming at 723K are shown in Fig. 10 . DRIFT spectrum at the beginning of reaction for Rh/A catalyst showed absorption bands corresponding to CO adsorbed over metallic Rh sites (at 1998 and 1800cm−1, associated with linear and bridged CO species) and weak bands at ca. 1570, 1460 and 1390cm−1 corresponding to acetate species. After 20min on stream, the absorption bands corresponding to CO decreased slightly while the acetate bands became more intense being the main adsorbed intermediates on the catalysts surfaces for long-time on stream. The promoted catalyst presented differences with respect to the species adsorbed on catalyst supported on bare alumina. On the modified catalysts a band at ca. 2020cm−1 was observed, associated with linear CO species adsorbed on Rh particles, with no bands associated to CO bridge species. Bands in the 1300 and 1700cm−1 region are associated with formate species coexisting with acetate and carbonate species. Intermediates accumulated on the surface with time on stream and, after 20min, acetate, formate and carbonate become the main adsorbed species over this catalyst. Absorption bands at 3015cm−1 (CH stretching) and 1305cm−1 (CH deformation) were attributed to gaseous methane and the band at 2360cm−1 was assigned to CO2 asymmetric stretching vibration. These results indicate that C1 products observed in gas phase arise from decomposition of acetaldehyde, acetate and formate intermediates (Eqs. (10), (18) and (19)) on promoted catalyst. This study suggests that acetate intermediaries may be responsible for the deactivation of the Rh/A catalyst because they are accumulate on its surface. They can also lead to the formation of acetone which was described previously. Conversely, modified catalyst with promoters oxides favours the decomposition of acetate species, preventing its accumulation. 4 Conclusions The modification of γ-Al2O3 with La2O3 and at a CeO2 loading between 2.5% and 10% improves the stability of the catalyst by decreasing carbon deposition rate. Adding appropriate amounts of rare earth oxides (i.e. 15wt% La2O3 and 5wt% CeO2) to Rh catalysts supported on bare alumina led to a high selectivityt to hydrogen, very low selectivity to C2 intermediates and improved stability up to 48h of time on stream at 773K. These observed characteristics are as as result of the reduction of strong Lewis acidity of γ-Al2O3 support and the ease of removing carbon deposits, which can be related to the close contact of the metallic site with the support promoters. An increase in carbon gasification was due to the combined effect of the formation of lanthanum oxycarbonate from the addition of La2O3 promoter and the highest amount of mobile lattice oxygen induced by the CeO2 promoter. On the other hand, the addition of a CeO2 loading above 15% had a negative effect on catalyst stability and the selectivity of Rh catalyst supported on alumina. Finally, reactivation tests showed that it is possible to recover part of the activity of the original catalyst after subjecting it to a pretreatment by oxidation and reduction in order to remove any carbon deposits which are potential causes of deactivation. coredata.dc:description: Rh-based catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3–La2O3 modified with CeO2 promoter were prepared in the present work. The objective was to study the promotional effect of the addition of different CeO2 contents and 15wt% La2O3 on the stability of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for ethanol steam reforming reaction. The physico-chemical characteristics of the catalysts, activity and the deposition of carbon on the catalyst surface were surveyed by NH3-TPD, XRD, TPR, XPS, DRIFT, TPO-TG and Raman. The stability of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was effectively improved by the addition of 15wt% La2O3 and 5wt% CeO2, as the carbon deposition rate was reduced significantly (from 2.3 to 0.16mgcoke gcat −1 h−1). The role of the promoter was to decrease the selectivity to ethylene by modification of Lewis acid sites on the support and the removal of carbon deposits during the reaction. This is achieved through the formation of lanthanum oxycarbonate from La2O3 and higher amount of mobile lattice oxygen induced by the CeO2 promoter. This catalyst exhibited good selectivity to H2, with no presence of C2 intermediates above 723K; in addition this catalyst was stable up to 48h of time on stream at 773K. Furthermore, the original activity of the catalyst was recovered through regeneration by the removal of some carbon deposits which are potential causes of deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Rh/Al2O3–La2O3 catalysts promoted with CeO2 for ethanol steam reforming reaction
